{"uri": "2024-06-380074254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:32:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/putin-warns-that-russia-could-provide-long-range-weapons-to-others-to-strike-western-targets/article_2abf2464-9616-5e1f-851d-01ab6a92a329.html", "title": "Putin warns that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks to senior news leaders of international news agencies on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum at the Lakhta Center skyscraper, the headquarters of Russian gas monopoly Gazprom in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Wednesday, June 5, 2024. The Russian leader has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors.\n\nST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step,\" and he said Moscow could in turn provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems.\" he said.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nBecause using such Western weapons for striking Russian territory involves military personnel of the respective countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, Putin said, Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps. That could include giving such weapons to others to target facilities of respective countries elsewhere in the world, he added.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he said\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": {"uri": "8163484897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:37:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:37:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:35:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.orilliamatters.com/world-news/putin-warns-that-russia-could-provide-long-range-weapons-to-others-to-strike-western-targets-8992234", "title": "Putin warns that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets", "body": "ST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step,\" and he said Moscow could in turn provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems.\" he said.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nBecause using such Western weapons for striking Russian territory involves military personnel of the respective countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, Putin said, Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps. That could include giving such weapons to others to target facilities of respective countries elsewhere in the world, he added.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he said\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.\n\nJames Jordan And Harriet Morris, The Associated PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step\" and he said Moscow could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems.\" he said.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nHe said the action by Germany could ruin relations between Berlin and Moscow.\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on a wide range of topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. {"uri": "8163464351", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:17:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:17:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:16:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/05/putin-warns-that-russia-could-provide-longrange-weapons-to-others-to-strike-western-targets/", "title": "Putin warns that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By James Jordan And Harriet Morris, The Associated Press on June 5, 2024.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin visits the Lakhta Center skyscraper, the headquarters of Russian gas monopoly Gazprom in St. Petersburg, Russia, Wednesday, June 5, 2024. (Alexander Zholobov, Sputnik, Kremlin Pool Photo via AP)ST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) - Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Wednesday that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets. His remarks came after he warned Germany that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step.\"\u009d THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below. ST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) - Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step\" and ruin relations between Berlin and Moscow. Germany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said. \"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\"\u009d he said. On Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity. Taking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November. \"We will work with any president the American people elect,\"\u009d Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum. \"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\"\u009d he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\u009d Putin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\u009d The Russian leader faced questions on a wide range of topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session. Asked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's. He also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia. The claims could not be independently verified. Putin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine. Last year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly - including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union - were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine. - - Associated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "label": {"eng": "Jordan"}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.388235294117647, "wgt": 216, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-380226248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:29:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:29:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:58:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.wlbt.com/2024/06/05/putin-says-nothing-will-change-terms-russia-us-relations-regardless-who-wins-us-election/", "title": "Putin warns that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets", "body": "ST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step,\" and he said Moscow could, in turn, provide long-range arms to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems,\" he said, speaking to senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nBecause using such Western weapons involves military personnel of those countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, Putin said Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps elsewhere in the world.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he told the journalists on the sidelines of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics, although the more than two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nPutin claimed the West had opportunities to end the fighting in Ukraine but did not act on them, citing a letter he once supposedly wrote to Biden that said hostilities could end in two or three months if Washington stopped supplying Kyiv with weapons.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nOn other topics, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure the release of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, an American jailed over a year ago while on a reporting trip and charged with espionage. Gershkovich, his employer and the U.S. have denied the allegations, and Washington has declared him to be wrongfully detained.\n\nPutin said that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added, an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nPutin has used the St. Petersburg forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "wlbt.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8163536026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:24:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:24:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:23:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/06/05/putin-threatens-to-supply-long-range-weapons-to-target-west/", "title": "Putin Threatens to Supply Long-Range Weapons to Target West", "body": "ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step,\" and he said Moscow could in turn provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems.\" he said.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nBecause using such Western weapons for striking Russian territory involves military personnel of the respective countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, Putin said, Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps. That could include giving such weapons to others to target facilities of respective countries elsewhere in the world, he added.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he said\n\nRelated Story: Israeli Nationalists March in Palestinian Area of Jerusalem, Some Chanting ...\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. {"uri": "8163466586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:19:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.dailypress.com/2024/06/05/putin-warns-that-russia-could-provide-long-range-weapons-to-others-to-strike-western-targets/", "title": "Putin warns that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets", "body": "By JAMES JORDAN and HARRIET MORRIS (Associated Press)\n\nST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step\" and he said Moscow could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems.\" he said.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nHe said the action by Germany could ruin relations between Berlin and Moscow.\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on a wide range of topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "dailypress.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-380027905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:55:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:55:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:35:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/05/putin-warns-germany-that-use-of-its-weapons-by-ukraine-to-strike-russia-will-mark-dangerous-step/", "title": "Putin warns Germany that use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike Russia will mark 'dangerous step'", "body": "ST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step\" and ruin relations between Berlin and Moscow.\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv.\n\nThe deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Joe Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on a wide range of topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the {"uri": "8163622616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:51:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:51:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:50:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20240605/putin-warns-russia-could-provide-weapons-others-strike-western-targets", "title": "Putin warns that Russia could provide weapons to others to strike Western targets", "body": "(AP) -- Russian President Vladimir Putin has warned Germany that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step,\" and said Moscow could, in turn, provide long-range arms to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems,\" he said Wednesday, speaking to senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nBecause using such Western weapons involves military personnel of those countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, Putin said Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps elsewhere in the world.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he told the journalists on the sidelines of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorising Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a US senator said Ukraine has used US weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden.\n\nIt allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorised to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-US relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics, although the more than two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nPutin claimed the West had opportunities to end the fighting in Ukraine but did not act on them, citing a letter he once supposedly wrote to Biden that said hostilities could end in two or three months if Washington stopped supplying Kyiv with weapons.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe {"uri": "8163650301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:25:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:25:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:19:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2731267/", "title": "Putin warns that Russia may provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets - ExBulletin", "body": "ST. PETERSBURG, President of Russia (AP). Vladimir Putin warned on Wednesday that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets in response to NATO allies allowing Ukraine to use their weapons to attack Russian territory.\n\nPutin also reaffirmed Moscow's readiness to use nuclear weapons if it sees a threat to its sovereignty.\n\nThe latest actions by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to very serious problems, he said, taking questions from international journalists, something that has become extremely rare since Moscow sent troops to Ukraine.\n\nThis would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act in the same way, Putin added.\n\nUnited States and Germany recently authorized Ukraine to strike some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons it is supplying to Kiev.\n\nWednesday, a Western official and a US senator said that Ukraine has used American weapons to strike inside Russia under the newly adopted guidelines by President Joe Biden allowing the use of US weapons for limited defense purposes Kharkiv, the second largest city of Ukraine. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nPutin asserted that the use of some Western-supplied weapons involves those countries' military personnel controlling the missiles and selecting targets, and therefore he said Moscow could take asymmetric steps elsewhere in the world. The US military said it does not control the missiles it provides to Ukraine or the targets.\n\nIf they consider it possible to send such weapons into the combat zone to launch attacks on our territory and create problems for us, why do we not have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch attacks on the sensitive facilities of countries that do this to Russia?\", he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he told reporters on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\nAsked if Russia could use nuclear weapons, Putin said that the conditions for using this arsenal are clearly defined in Moscow's security doctrine.\n\nFor some reason, they believe in the West that Russia will never use it, he said.\n\nLook at what is written there, he said of Russia's nuclear doctrine. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible to use all the means at our disposal.\n\nEven Russian battlefield nuclear weapons are far more powerful than those used by the US against Japan in World War II, Putin said.\n\nSpeaking to senior news executives from international news agencies, including the Associated Press, for more than three hours, Putin also said nothing will change about Russia-US relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the election. US presidential election in November.\n\nWe will work with whatever president the American people choose, Putin said.\n\nI say absolutely honestly, I would not say that we believe that after the election something will change in the Russian way in American politics, he added. We don't think so. We think that nothing serious will happen.\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction in his hush money trial last week was the result of \"using the court system as part of political infighting.\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on a variety of topics, although more than two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nPutin claimed the West had options to end the fighting in Ukraine but failed to act on them, citing a letter he allegedly once wrote to Biden in which he said hostilities could end within two or three months if Washington stopped the supply of weapons to Kiev.\n\nAsked about Russian military casualties, Putin said no country would reveal that information during hostilities, but claimed without elaborating that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified, and some Western estimates put Russia's losses far higher than Ukraine's.\n\nAsked by the AP about the case of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, Putin said the US is taking vigorous steps to secure his release. Gershkovich was jailed over a year ago while on a reporting trip and charged with espionage. The journalist, his employer and the US have denied the charges and Washington has declared him wrongly arrested.\n\nPutin said that any such publication is not decided through the mass media, but through a measured, calm and professional approach.\n\nAnd they should certainly only be established on the basis of reciprocity, he added, hinting at a possible prisoner exchange.\n\nPutin has used it St. Petersburg Forum as a showcase for advertising Russia's development and seeking investors. The meeting with journalists took place at Gazprom's new global headquarters, an 81-story needle-shaped skyscraper overlooking the Gulf of Finland.\n\nWhile meetings with reporters were part of previous hearings, he has not taken questions from Western reporters at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries Russia considers unfriendly, including the US, UK and European Union, were not invited, and Western officials and investors also walked out of the session after broad sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine. .\n\n-\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-380167324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:27:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:27:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:25:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20240605-putin-warns-that-russia-could-supply-weapons-to-others-to-strike-western-targets", "title": "Putin warns Russia could supply weapons to others to strike Western targets", "body": "President Vladimir Putin warned Wednesday that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets in response to NATO allies allowing Ukraine to use their arms to attack Russian territory.\n\nPutin also reaffirmed Moscow's readiness to use nuclear weapons if it sees a threat to its sovereignty.\n\nThe recent actions by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems,\" he said, taking questions from international journalists -- something that has become extremely rare since Moscow sent troops into Ukraine.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nThe United States and Germany recently authorised Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a US senator said Ukraine has used US weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden that allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorised to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nPutin claimed that using some Western-supplied weapons involves military personnel of those countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, and therefore he said Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps elsewhere in the world. The US military said it does not control the missiles it provides to Ukraine or the targets.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he told the journalists on the sidelines of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\nAsked whether Russia could resort to using nuclear arms, Putin said the conditions for utilising that arsenal are clearly spelled out in Moscow's security doctrine.\n\n\"For some reason, they believe in the West that Russia will never use it,\" he said.\n\n\"Look at what is written there,\" he said of Russia's nuclear doctrine. \"If somebody's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible to use all means at our disposal.\"\n\nEven Russia's battlefield nuclear weapons are much more powerful than what the US used against Japan in World War II, Putin said.\n\nSpeaking to senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, for more than three hours, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-US relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics, although the more than two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nPutin claimed the West had opportunities to end the fighting in Ukraine but did not act on them, citing a letter he once supposedly wrote to Biden that said hostilities could end in two or three months if Washington stopped supplying Kyiv with weapons.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified and some Western estimates put Russia's losses much higher than Ukraine's.\n\nAsked by AP about the case of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, Putin said the US is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. Gershkovich was jailed over a year ago while on a reporting trip and charged with espionage. The journalist, his employer and the US have denied the allegations, and Washington has declared him to be wrongfully detained.\n\nPutin said that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added, an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nPutin has used the St. Petersburg forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. The meeting with journalists took place in Gazprom's new global headquarters, a needle-shaped 81-story skyscraper overlooking the Gulf of Finland.\n\nWhile meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the US, the UK and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nPutin claimed that using some Western-supplied weapons involves military personnel of those countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, and therefore he said Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps elsewhere in the world. The U.S. military said it does not control the missiles it provides to Ukraine or the targets.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\" he said.\n\n\"We will think about it,\" he told the journalists on the sidelines of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\nAsked whether Russia could resort to using nuclear arms, Putin said the conditions for utilizing that arsenal are clearly spelled out in Moscow's security doctrine.\n\n\"For some reason, they believe in the West that Russia will never use it,\" he said.\n\n\"Look at what is written there,\" he said of Russia's nuclear doctrine. \"If somebody's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible to use all means at our disposal.\"\n\nEven Russia's battlefield nuclear weapons are much more powerful than what the U.S. used against Japan in World War II, Putin said.\n\nSpeaking to senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, for more than three hours, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics, although the more than two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nPutin claimed the West had opportunities to end the fighting in Ukraine but did not act on them, citing a letter he once supposedly wrote to Biden that said hostilities could end in two or three months if Washington stopped supplying Kyiv with weapons.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified and some Western estimates put Russia's losses much higher than Ukraine's.\n\nAsked by AP about the case of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, Putin said the U.S. is \"taking energetic steps\" to secure his release. Gershkovich was jailed over a year ago while on a reporting trip and charged with espionage. The journalist, his employer and the U.S. have denied the allegations, and Washington has declared him to be wrongfully detained.\n\nPutin said that any such releases \"aren't decided via mass media\" but through a \"discreet, calm and professional approach.\"\n\n\"And they certainly should be decided only on the basis of reciprocity,\" he added, an allusion to a potential prisoner swap.\n\nPutin has used the St. Petersburg forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. The meeting with journalists took place in Gazprom's new global headquarters, a needle-shaped 81-story skyscraper overlooking the Gulf of Finland.\n\nWhile meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "opb.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "opb"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-06-380032018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:00:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:00:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:35:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.mcall.com/2024/06/05/putin-warns-germany-that-use-of-its-weapons-by-ukraine-to-strike-russia-will-mark-dangerous-step/", "title": "Putin warns Germany that use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike Russia will mark 'dangerous step'", "body": "By JAMES JORDAN and HARRIET MORRIS (Associated Press)\n\nST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \"dangerous step\" and ruin relations between Berlin and Moscow.\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv.\n\nThe deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\"Now if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\" he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a U.S. senator said Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from President Joe Biden. It allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-U.S. relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\"We will work with any president the American people elect,\" Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\"I say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn't say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\" he added. \"We don't think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\"\n\nPutin also said Trump's felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \"the use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle.\"\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on a wide range of topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, including The Associated Press, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine's casualties are five times greater than Russia's.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia's development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly -- including the U.S., the U.K. and the European Union -- were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of the session after wide-ranging sanctions were imposed on Moscow over Ukraine.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Aamer Madhani in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "mcall.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-380258015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "01:40:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T01:40:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:33:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/world/globaltalk/putin-russia-nukes/2024/06/05/id/1167631/", "title": "Putin Says Russia Could Deploy Missiles in Striking Distance of West", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday he could deploy conventional missiles within striking distance of the United States and its European allies if they allowed Ukraine to strike deeper into Russia with long-range Western weapons.\n\nPutin, in his first face-to-face meeting with senior editors of international news agencies since the war in Ukraine began, said the West was wrong to assume Russia would never use nuclear weapons, and said the Kremlin's nuclear doctrine should not be taken lightly.\n\nWhen asked about NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg's calls to allow Ukraine to use Western weapons to strike Russian territory, Putin differentiated between different missiles but warned allowing Kyiv to strike Russia with ever more powerful weapons was a serious escalation that was drawing the West towards a war with Russia.\n\nRussia's response, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said, would be to shoot down the Western missiles, and specifically mentioned U.S. ATACMS, and British and French missile systems.\n\nPutin also said Moscow was considering deploying similar high-technology, long-range missiles close enough to strike the states that allowed Ukraine to strike Russian territory with such missiles.\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems,\" Putin said.\n\nPutin did not give specifics of where he was considering delivering such missiles.\n\nPresident Joe Biden authorized Kyiv to launch some U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia. Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons.\n\nBritish Foreign Secretary David Cameron, during a visit to Kyiv on May 3, told Reuters Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by Britain to strike targets inside Russia, and it was up to Kyiv whether to do so.\n\nNUCLEAR RISK\n\nSpeaking to journalists for more than three hours at the newly built 81-floor Gazprom tower ahead of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, Putin touched on subjects from the war in Gaza to the upcoming U.S. election.\n\n\"No one in the United States is interested in Ukraine, they are interested in the greatness of the United States, which is fighting not for Ukraine and the Ukrainian people, but for its own greatness.\"\n\nPutin said Russia did not care who the next U.S. president was but said the U.S. court system was clearly being used in a political battle against Republican nominee Donald Trump.\n\n\"They are burning themselves from the inside, their state, their political system ... It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump, especially in court on charges that were formed on the basis of events that happened years ago, without direct proof, is simply using the judicial system in an internal political struggle,\" said Putin.\n\nMore than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Putin is increasingly talking of the risk of a global conflict as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWhen asked about the risk of nuclear war, Putin said Russia's nuclear doctrine allowed the use of such weapons.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nRussia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nNATO ATTACK?\n\nPutin casts the conflict in Ukraine as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a U.S.-backed coup.\n\nThe West describes the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control and which Moscow now considers to be parts of Russia.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia but have repeatedly warned Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance.\n\nBoth Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, and U.S.-led NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said.\n\n\"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsMax"}, "authors": [{"uri": "guy_faulconbridge@newsmax.com", "name": "Guy Faulconbridge", "type": "author", {"uri": "8163787597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "01:17:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T01:17:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T01:15:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/putin-says-russia-could-deploy-missiles-in-striking-distance-of-the-west/articleshow/110751923.cms", "title": "Putin says Russia could deploy missiles in striking distance of the West", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin warned of deploying missiles near the US and its allies if Ukraine uses Western weapons. He emphasized Russia's nuclear capabilities and criticized NATO's stance on the conflict.Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday he could deploy conventional missiles within striking distance of the United States and its European allies if they allowed Ukraine to strike deeper into Russia with long-range Western weapons.\n\nPutin, in his first face-to-face meeting with senior editors of international news agencies since the war in Ukraine began, said the West was wrong to assume Russia would never use nuclear weapons, and said the Kremlin's nuclear doctrine should not be taken lightly.\n\nWhen asked about NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg's calls to allow Ukraine to use Western weapons to strike Russian territory, Putin differentiated between different missiles but warned allowing Kyiv to strike Russia with ever more powerful weapons was a serious escalation that was drawing the West towards a war with Russia.\n\nRussia's response, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said, would be to shoot down the Western missiles, and specifically mentioned U.S. ATACMS, and British and French missile systems.\n\nPutin also said Moscow was considering deploying similar high-technology, long-range missiles close enough to strike the states that allowed Ukraine to strike Russian territory with such missiles.\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems,\" Putin said.\n\nPutin did not give specifics of where he was considering delivering such missiles.\n\nPresident Joe Biden authorized Kyiv to launch some U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia. Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons.\n\nBritish Foreign Secretary David Cameron, during a visit to Kyiv on May 3, told Reuters Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by Britain to strike targets inside Russia, and it was up to Kyiv whether to do so.\n\nNUCLEAR RISK\n\nSpeaking to journalists for more than three hours at the newly built 81-floor Gazprom tower ahead of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, Putin touched on subjects from the war in Gaza to the upcoming U.S. election.\n\n\"No one in the United States is interested in Ukraine, they are interested in the greatness of the United States, which is fighting not for Ukraine and the Ukrainian people, but for its own greatness.\"\n\nPutin said Russia did not care who the next U.S. president was but said the U.S. court system was clearly being used in a political battle against Republican nominee Donald Trump.\n\n\"They are burning themselves from the inside, their state, their political system ... It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump, especially in court on charges that were formed on the basis of events that happened years ago, without direct proof, is simply using the judicial system in an internal political struggle,\" said Putin.\n\nMore than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Putin is increasingly talking of the risk of a global conflict as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWhen asked about the risk of nuclear war, Putin said Russia's nuclear doctrine allowed the use of such weapons.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nRussia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nNATO ATTACK?\n\nPutin casts the conflict in Ukraine as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a U.S.-backed coup.\n\nThe West describes the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control and which Moscow now considers to be parts of Russia.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia but have repeatedly warned Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance.\n\nBoth Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, and U.S.-led NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said.\n\n\"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\"", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyiv", "type": "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/russia-central-asia/article/3265540/ukraine-war-russias-putin-threatens-arm-countries-could-hit-western-targets", "title": "Russia's Putin threatens to arm countries that could hit Western targets", "body": "He warned that Moscow would respond if Kyiv took the \u2018dangerous step\u2019 of using German weapons to strike Russian soil\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin warned Germany on Wednesday that the use of its weapons by Ukraine to strike targets inside Russia would mark a \u201cdangerous step\u201d, and he said Moscow could in turn provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets.\n\nSuch action by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \u201cvery serious problems\u201d. he said.\n\n\u201cThat would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\u201d Putin added.\n\nBecause using such Western weapons for striking Russian territory involves military personnel of the respective countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, Putin said, Moscow could take \u201casymmetrical\u201d steps.\n\nThat could include giving such weapons to others to target facilities of respective countries elsewhere in the world, he added.\n\n\u201cIf they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don\u2019t we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cWe will think about it,\u201d he said\n\nGermany joined the United States recently in authorising Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv. The deliveries of German tanks to Ukraine came as a shock to many in Russia, he said.\n\n\u201cNow if they use missiles to strike facilities on the Russian territory, it will completely ruin Russian-German relations,\u201d he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a Western official and a US senator said Ukraine has used American weapons to strike inside Russia under newly approved guidance from US President Joe Biden.\n\nIt allows American arms to be used for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine\u2019s second-largest city. The official was not authorised to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nTaking questions from international journalists for the first time since his inauguration last month to a fifth term, Putin also said nothing will change in terms of Russia-US relations regardless of whether Biden or Donald Trump wins the American presidential election in November.\n\n\u201cWe will work with any president the American people elect,\u201d Putin said, speaking on the sidelines of the St Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\n\u201cI say absolutely sincerely, I wouldn\u2019t say that we believe that after the election something will change on the Russian track in the American politics,\u201d he added. \u201cWe don\u2019t think so. We think nothing that serious will happen.\u201d\n\nPutin also said Trump\u2019s felony conviction at his hush money trial last week was the result of \u201cthe use of the court system as part of the internal political struggle\u201d.\n\nThe Russian leader faced questions on various topics from senior news leaders of international news agencies, although the over two years of fighting in Ukraine dominated the session.\n\nAsked about Russian military losses, Putin said that no country would reveal that information during hostilities but claimed without providing details that Ukraine\u2019s casualties are five times greater than Russia\u2019s.\n\nHe also said Ukraine has more than 1,300 Russian troops in captivity, while more than 6,400 Ukrainian soldiers are being held in Russia.\n\nThe claims could not be independently verified.\n\nPutin has used the annual forum as a showcase for touting Russia\u2019s development and seeking investors. While meetings with journalists were part of previous sessions, he has not taken questions from Western journalists at the St. Petersburg event since sending troops to Ukraine.\n\nLast year, journalists from countries that Russia regards as unfriendly \u2013 including the US, the UK and the European Union \u2013 were not invited, and Western officials and investors also steered clear of
