{"uri": "8163724974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:56:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:56:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:55:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/news/world/putin-says-russia-could-put-missiles-striking-distance-west", "title": "Putin says Russia could put missiles in striking distance of the West", "body": "Putin, in his first face-to-face meeting with senior editors of international news agencies since the war in Ukraine began, said the West was wrong to assume Russia would never use nuclear weapons, and said the Kremlin's nuclear doctrine should not be taken lightly.\n\nWhen asked about NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg's calls to allow Ukraine to use Western weapons to strike Russian territory, Putin differentiated between different missiles but warned allowing Kyiv to strike Russia with ever more powerful weapons was a serious escalation that was drawing the West towards a war with Russia.\n\nRussia's response, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said, would be to shoot down the Western missiles, and specifically mentioned US ATACMS, and British and French missile systems.\n\nPutin also said Moscow was considering deploying similar high-technology, long-range missiles close enough to strike the states that allowed Ukraine to strike Russian territory with such missiles.\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems,\" Putin said.\n\nHe spoke to journalists for more than three hours at the newly built 81-floor Gazprom tower ahead of the annual St. Petersburg International Economic Forum.\n\nPutin did not give specifics of where he was considering delivering such missiles.\n\nRussia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022 touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis and the Kremlin has repeatedly warned the risk of a global war is rising.\n\nPresident Joe Biden authorized Kyiv to launch some US-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia. Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range US-supplied weapons.\n\nBritish Foreign Secretary David Cameron, during a visit to Kyiv on May 3, told Reuters Ukraine had a right to use the weapons provided by Britain to strike targets inside Russia, and it was up to Kyiv whether to do so.\n\nMore than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Putin is increasingly talking of the risk of a global conflict as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWhen asked about the risk of nuclear war, Putin said Russia's nuclear doctrine allowed the use of such weapons.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nRussia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nPutin dismissed Western assertions that Russia has employed nuclear sabre rattling and pointed out the US was the only country to have used nuclear weapons in war - attacking the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nPutin casts the war as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a US-backed coup.\n\nThe West describes the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control and which Moscow now considers to be parts of Russia.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia but have repeatedly warned Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance.\n\nBoth Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, and US-led NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said.\n\n\"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? {"uri": "8163602530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:30:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:30:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:29:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13499321/Putin-threatens-arm-countries-hit-Western-targets.html", "title": "Putin threatens to arm countries that could hit Western targets", "body": "Putin was speaking at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday criticised the West's delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack Western targets.\n\nThe comment -- which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets -- came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\nBut the 71-year-old Kremlin chief dismissed as \"bollocks\" suggestions Russia planned to attack NATO members.\n\n\"There is no need to look for some imperial ambitions of ours. There are none,\" he said.\n\nPutin warned that Western arms deliveries to Ukraine were \"a very negative step\", saying that donors were \"controlling\" the weapons.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany for particular criticism, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\n- 'Irrecoverable losses' -\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\nPutin told the media outlets Russia had no \"imperial\" ambitions\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin rebuffed, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure.\n\n\"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"\n\n- 'Burned to the ground' -\n\nPutin was also probed about what a victory for former US President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for US-Russia relations -- an issue the Russian leader shrugged off.\n\n\"By and large there's no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever he called Trump's recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilisation of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said.\n\nRussia has criticised Western arms supplies to Ukraine, arguing they only 'prolong' the conflict\n\n\"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nTrump became the first former US head of state ever convicted of a crime last week after a New York jury found him guilty of 34 felony charges in a hush money case.\n\nTrump, who faces an election in November that could see him return to the White House, has praised Putin as a \"smart guy\".\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed US journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the US and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" {"uri": "8163602506", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:58:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:58:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:29:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13499383/Putin-says-West-wrong-assume-Russia-never-use-nuclear-weapons.html", "title": "Putin says West is wrong to assume Russia would never use nuclear...", "body": "Putin: Russia may send missiles closer to West\n\n*\n\nPutin: West should read Russia's nuclear doctrine\n\n*\n\nWestern weapons hitting Russia is a step to war\n\n*\n\nPutin: Russia will not attack NATO\n\n(Recasts headline and lead)\n\nBy Samia Nakhoul and Guy Faulconbridge\n\nST PETERSBURG, Russia, June 5 (Reuters) -\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday that the West was wrong to assume that Moscow would never use nuclear weapons and said that he was considering deploying conventional missiles in striking distance of the United States and its allies.\n\nRussia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022 touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis - and the Kremlin has repeatedly warned that the risk of a global war is rising.\n\nPutin, speaking face-to-face to senior editors of\n\ninternational news agencies\n\nfor the first time since the war in Ukraine began, dismissed Western claims that Russia could attack NATO as \"stupid\", citing the military strength of the alliance.\n\nBut when asked about the risk of nuclear war, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said that Russia's nuclear doctrine did allow the use of such weapons if the country's territorial integrity or sovereignty was threatened.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nRussia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nPutin dismissed Western assertions that Russia has employed nuclear sabre rattling and pointed out that the United States was the only country to have used nuclear weapons in war - attacking the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMISSILES\n\nPutin warned that Western decisions to allow Ukraine to use ever more powerful Western missiles to strike into Russian territory was a serious escalation, and said that such weapons would have to be guided by Western systems and personnel.\n\nPresident Joe Biden authorized Kyiv\n\nto launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia, but Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons.\n\nAsked about the Western decisions, Putin differentiated between different weapons but said that the use of ATACMS or British Storm Shadow missiles against Russia could lead to a tougher response from Moscow.\n\n\"We will improve our air defence systems and destroy them,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Secondly, we are thinking that if someone thinks it possible to send such weapons to a war zone to strike our territory and create problems for us, then why do we not have the right to send our weapons of the same class to those regions of the world where strikes can be made on sensitive facilities of the countries that do this against Russia. That is to say, the response can be asymmetric.\"\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems.\"\n\nPutin casts the war as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a coup backed by the United States.\n\nThe West dismisses Putin's analysis of the conflict, and casts the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control - and which Russia now considers to be parts of Russia.\n\nMore than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Russia's leader is increasingly talking of the risk of a global war as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, but have repeatedly warned that Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance led by the United States.\n\nBoth Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia and NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said.\n\n\"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\" (Additional reporting by Vladimir Soldatkin; Editing by Andrew Osborn)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-380132194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:24:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:24:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-05/putin-says-west-is-wrong-to-assume-russia-would-never-use-nuclear-weapons", "title": "Putin Says West Is Wrong to Assume Russia Would Never Use Nuclear Weapons", "body": "ST PETERSBURG, Russia (Reuters) - Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday that the West was wrong to assume that Moscow would never use nuclear weapons and said that he was considering deploying conventional missiles in striking distance of the United States and its allies.\n\nRussia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022 touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis - and the Kremlin has repeatedly warned that the risk of a global war is rising.\n\nPutin, speaking face-to-face to senior editors of international news agencies for the first time since the war in Ukraine began, dismissed Western claims that Russia could attack NATO as \"stupid\", citing the military strength of the alliance.\n\nBut when asked about the risk of nuclear war, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said that Russia's nuclear doctrine did allow the use of such weapons if the country's territorial integrity or sovereignty was threatened.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nRussia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nPutin dismissed Western assertions that Russia has employed nuclear sabre rattling and pointed out that the United States was the only country to have used nuclear weapons in war - attacking the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMISSILES\n\nPutin warned that Western decisions to allow Ukraine to use ever more powerful Western missiles to strike into Russian territory was a serious escalation, and said that such weapons would have to be guided by Western systems and personnel.\n\nPresident Joe Biden authorized Kyiv to launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia, but Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons.\n\nAsked about the Western decisions, Putin differentiated between different weapons but said that the use of ATACMS or British Storm Shadow missiles against Russia could lead to a tougher response from Moscow.\n\n\"We will improve our air defence systems and destroy them,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Secondly, we are thinking that if someone thinks it possible to send such weapons to a war zone to strike our territory and create problems for us, then why do we not have the right to send our weapons of the same class to those regions of the world where strikes can be made on sensitive facilities of the countries that do this against Russia. That is to say, the response can be asymmetric.\"\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems.\"\n\nPutin casts the war as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a coup backed by the United States.\n\nThe West dismisses Putin's analysis of the conflict, and casts the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control - and which Russia now considers to be parts of Russia.\n\nMore than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Russia's leader is increasingly talking of the risk of a global war as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, but have repeatedly warned that Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance led by the United States.\n\nBoth Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia and NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said.\n\n\"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\"\n\n(Additional reporting by Vladimir Soldatkin; Editing by Andrew Osborn)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8163626852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:01:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:01:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:55:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/putin-threatens-to-arm-countries-that-could-hit-western-targets", "title": "Putin threatens to arm countries that could hit Western targets", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday criticized the West's delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack Western targets.\n\nThe comment -- which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets -- came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a war zone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a war zone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasize that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure. \"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five.\"\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said. \"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a war zone.\"\n\nPutin was also asked about what a victory for former U.S. President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for U.S.-Russia relations -- an issue the Russian leader shrugged off.\n\n\"By and large there's no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever, he called Trump's recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilization of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nTrump became the first former U.S. head of state ever convicted of a crime last week after a New York jury found him guilty of 34 felony charges in a hush money case.\n\nTrump, who faces an election in November that could see him return to the White House, has praised Putin as a \"smart guy\".\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the U.S. and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" Putin said.\n\n\u00a9 2024 AFP", "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Japan Today"}, {"uri": "8163590716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:17:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:17:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:16:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2973271-putins-warning-nuclear-doctrine-and-the-risk-of-global-war", "title": "Putin's Warning: Nuclear Doctrine and the Risk of Global War | Law-Order", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin addressed western assumptions about Russia's use of nuclear weapons, emphasizing that Moscow's nuclear doctrine allows for such weaponry if the nation's sovereignty is under threat. He warned against escalating arms supplies to Ukraine, hinting at possible asymmetric responses and noting the significant risks of global conflict.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday that the West was wrong to assume that Moscow would never use nuclear weapons and said that he was considering deploying conventional missiles in striking distance of the United States and its allies.\n\nRussia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022 touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis - and the Kremlin has repeatedly warned that the risk of a global war is rising. Putin, speaking face-to-face to senior editors of\n\ninternational news agencies for the first time since the war in Ukraine began, dismissed Western claims that Russia could attack NATO as \"stupid\", citing the military strength of the alliance.\n\nBut when asked about the risk of nuclear war, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said that Russia's nuclear doctrine did allow the use of such weapons if the country's territorial integrity or sovereignty was threatened. \"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\" Russia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nPutin dismissed Western assertions that Russia has employed nuclear sabre rattling and pointed out that the United States was the only country to have used nuclear weapons in war - attacking the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. MISSILES\n\nPutin warned that Western decisions to allow Ukraine to use ever more powerful Western missiles to strike into Russian territory was a serious escalation, and said that such weapons would have to be guided by Western systems and personnel. President Joe Biden authorized Kyiv\n\nto launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia, but Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons. Asked about the Western decisions, Putin differentiated between different weapons but said that the use of ATACMS or British Storm Shadow missiles against Russia could lead to a tougher response from Moscow.\n\n\"We will improve our air defence systems and destroy them,\" Putin said. \"Secondly, we are thinking that if someone thinks it possible to send such weapons to a war zone to strike our territory and create problems for us, then why do we not have the right to send our weapons of the same class to those regions of the world where strikes can be made on sensitive facilities of the countries that do this against Russia. That is to say, the response can be asymmetric.\"\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems.\" Putin casts the war as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a coup backed by the United States. The West dismisses Putin's analysis of the conflict, and casts the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control - and which Russia now considers to be parts of Russia. More than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Russia's leader is increasingly talking of the risk of a global war as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, but have repeatedly warned that Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance led by the United States. Both Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia and NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said. \"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\" (Additional reporting by Vladimir Soldatkin; Editing by Andrew Osborn)\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", {"uri": "8163680198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:00:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:00:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:57:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/1197363-putin-threatens-to-arm-countries-to-hit-western-targets", "title": "Putin threatens to arm countries to hit Western targets", "body": "SAINT PETERSBURG: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday criticised the West\u00b4s delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack Western targets.\n\nThe comment -- which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets -- came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don\u00b4t we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia\u00b4s battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine\u00b4s were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure. \"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"\n\nPutin was also probed about what a victory for former US President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for US-Russia relations -- an issue the Russian leader shrugged off. \"By and large there\u00b4s no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever he called Trump\u00b4s recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilisation of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said. \"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed US journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the US and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" Putin said.", {"uri": "8163610994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:38:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:38:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:37:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/putin-says-west-is-wrong-to-assume-russia-would-never-use-nuclear-weapons/article_78d2bcdc-9093-55e5-97f4-3c9e79b75315.html", "title": "Putin says West is wrong to assume Russia would never use nuclear weapons", "body": "By Samia Nakhoul and Guy Faulconbridge\n\nST PETERSBURG, Russia (Reuters) - Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday that the West was wrong to assume that Moscow would never use nuclear weapons and said that he was considering deploying conventional missiles in striking distance of the United States and its allies.\n\nRussia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022 touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis - and the Kremlin has repeatedly warned that the risk of a global war is rising.\n\nPutin, speaking face-to-face to senior editors of international news agencies for the first time since the war in Ukraine began, dismissed Western claims that Russia could attack NATO as \"stupid\", citing the military strength of the alliance.\n\nBut when asked about the risk of nuclear war, the 71-year-old Kremlin chief said that Russia's nuclear doctrine did allow the use of such weapons if the country's territorial integrity or sovereignty was threatened.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin said when asked by Reuters about the risk of nuclear escalation over Ukraine during more than three hours of questioning.\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine, look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nRussia's published 2020 nuclear doctrine sets out the conditions under which a Russian president would consider using a nuclear weapon: broadly as a response to an attack using nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or to the use of conventional weapons against Russia \"when the very existence of the state is put under threat.\"\n\nPutin dismissed Western assertions that Russia has employed nuclear sabre rattling and pointed out that the United States was the only country to have used nuclear weapons in war - attacking the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.\n\nMISSILES\n\nPutin warned that Western decisions to allow Ukraine to use ever more powerful Western missiles to strike into Russian territory was a serious escalation, and said that such weapons would have to be guided by Western systems and personnel.\n\nPresident Joe Biden authorized Kyiv to launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia, but Washington still prohibits Kyiv from striking Russia with ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons.\n\nAsked about the Western decisions, Putin differentiated between different weapons but said that the use of ATACMS or British Storm Shadow missiles against Russia could lead to a tougher response from Moscow.\n\n\"We will improve our air defence systems and destroy them,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Secondly, we are thinking that if someone thinks it possible to send such weapons to a war zone to strike our territory and create problems for us, then why do we not have the right to send our weapons of the same class to those regions of the world where strikes can be made on sensitive facilities of the countries that do this against Russia. That is to say, the response can be asymmetric.\"\n\n\"If we see that these countries are being drawn into a war against the Russian Federation, then we reserve the right to act in the same way. In general, this is a path to very serious problems.\"\n\nPutin casts the war as part of an existential battle with a declining and decadent West which he says humiliated Russia after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 by encroaching on what he considers Moscow's sphere of influence, including Ukraine.\n\nPutin said the West refused to speak about the causes of the war - which he said started in 2014 after a pro-Russian president was toppled in Ukraine's Maidan Revolution. Putin cast it as a coup backed by the United States.\n\nThe West dismisses Putin's analysis of the conflict, and casts the invasion as an imperial-style land grab and has vowed to help Ukraine defeat Russian forces.\n\nUkraine says it will not rest until every last Russian soldier is ejected from the areas of Ukraine they control - and which Russia now considers to be parts of Russia.\n\nMore than two years into the deadliest land war in Europe since World War Two, Russia's leader is increasingly talking of the risk of a global war as the West grapples with what to do about the advance of Russian troops in Ukraine.\n\nWestern leaders and Ukraine have played down Russia's warnings about the risk of a broader war involving Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, but have repeatedly warned that Putin might attack a member of NATO, the world's most powerful military alliance led by the United States.\n\nBoth Putin and Biden have said that a direct conflict between Russia and NATO would be a step towards World War Three.\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said.\n\n\"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO. Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\"\n\n(Additional reporting by Vladimir Soldatkin; Editing by Andrew Osborn)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "2024-06-380154340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:04:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:04:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:03:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/684207/international/putin-vows-to-pay-back-west-in-same-coin", "title": "Putin vows to pay back West in same coin", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks with heads of International news agencies in Saint Petersburg on Wednesday. (AFP)\n\nSays allowing Ukraine to target Russia with their arms is a serious, dangerous step AFP Saint Petersburg Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday criticised the West's delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack Western targets.\n\nThe comment -- which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets -- came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no-one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure.\n\n\"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gulf-Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure.\n\n\"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"\n\nPutin was also probed about what a victory for former US President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for US-Russia relations -- an issue the Russian leader shrugged off.\n\n\"By and large there's no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever he called Trump's recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilisation of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nTrump became the first former US head of state ever convicted of a crime last week after a New York jury found him guilty of 34 felony charges in a hush money case.\n\nTrump, who faces an election in November that could see him return to the White House, has praised Putin as a \"smart guy\".\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed US journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the US and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" Putin said.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "8163511149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:02:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:02:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:01:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/putin-threatens-arm-countries-could-195650627.html", "title": "Putin threatens to arm countries that could hit Western targets", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday criticised the West's delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack Western targets.\n\nThe comment -- which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets -- came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\n- 'Irrecoverable losses' -\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure.\n\n\"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"\n\n- 'Burned to the ground' -\n\nPutin was also probed about what a victory for former US President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for US-Russia relations -- an issue the Russian leader shrugged off.\n\n\"By and large there's no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever he called Trump's recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilisation of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nTrump became the first former US head of state ever convicted of a crime last week after a New York jury found him guilty of 34 felony charges in a hush money case.\n\nTrump, who faces an election in November that could see him return to the White House, has praised Putin as a \"smart guy\".\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed US journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the US and Russia are {"uri": "8163638263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:07:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:07:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:06:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.rferl.org/a/putin-russia-ukraine-nuclear-europe-us/32980827.html", "title": "Putin Threatens To Send Arms To Countries That Could Attack Kyiv's Allies", "body": "Russian President Vladimir Putin warned on June 5 that Russia could provide advanced long-range weapons to Western adversaries in an \"asymmetric\" response to Ukrainian missile strikes deep into Russian territory.\n\nPutin, speaking in rare press conference with foreign news organizations at Russia's annual economic forum in St Petersburg, said Russia was thinking of delivering such weapons to regions of the world from which they could strike the countries that are supplying weapons to Ukraine.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those [Western] countries?\" Putin asked.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\nHis remarks came after U.S. President Joe Biden last week gave Ukraine the go-ahead to use U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending the eastern city of Kharkiv. Germany announced a similar change in policy shortly afterward.\n\nThe changes followed pleas from Ukraine to allow its forces to defend itself against attacks originating from Russian territory, and after pressure from some European leaders.\n\nRussia in recent weeks has stepped up strikes on civilian targets in the northeastern region of Kharkiv and in the eastern region of Donetsk.\n\nPutin warned that Western arms deliveries to Ukraine were \"a very dangerous step,\" especially if donors are \"controlling\" use of the weapons.\n\nHe specifically warned Germany, saying that talk of it sending missiles capable of hitting targets on Russian territory \"definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nOn the use of nuclear weapons, Putin cited Russia's nuclear doctrine, which says if Russia's sovereignty and territorial integrity is threatened \"we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal.\"\n\nPutin also reiterated his claim that Russia \"did not start the war,\" blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\nPutin has falsely claimed that months of massive and mostly peaceful protests that began in 2013 and lasted into early 2014 on Kyiv's Maidan Square were a U.S.-backed coup. The protests resulted in the ouster of Russian-friendly President Viktor Yanukovych, but not before a crackdown that left more than 100 people dead.\n\nRussia's response was to illegally annex Crimea and back a separatist rebellion in the east of the country.\n\nEight years later, in February 2022, despite weeks of warnings that Russia risked isolation and serious financial consequences if it invaded Ukraine, Moscow sent its forces into the country in a full-scale invasion.\n\nPutin was also asked about the U.S. presidential election and what a victory for former President Donald Trump or incumbent President Joe Biden would mean for U.S.-Russia relations.\n\n\"For the most part, we do not care\" who wins the U.S. election, he said, saying that Russia did not expect the November 5 election to change U.S. policy toward Russia, and Russia will work with any president the American people elect.\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in contact over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the U.S. and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" Putin said.\n\nThere was no mention of other Americans currently behind bars in Russia, including RFE/RL journalist We will think about it.\"\n\nHe did not specify which countries Moscow could supply weapons to.\n\nMr Putin singled out Germany, which recently told Ukraine it was free to hit targets inside Russia with long-range German-made weapons.\n\n\"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations,\" Mr Putin said.\n\nUS President Joe Biden has given Ukraine permission to use American-supplied weapons to strike targets in Russia, but only near the Kharkiv region. The White House has said Ukraine cannot use long-range ATACMS missiles on Russian soil.\n\nUkraine has used US weapons to strike inside Russia in recent days, a US senator and a Western official told the Associated Press on Wednesday.\n\nFierce fighting has been raging north-east of Kharkiv since a new Russian push across Ukraine's northern border. {"uri": "8163544605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:34:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:34:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:33:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/putin-threatens-to-arm-countries-that-could-hit-western-targets/article_867d1a6f-066b-5421-86c0-e612c5581f7c.html", "title": "Putin threatens to arm countries that could hit Western targets", "body": "Russia has criticised Western arms supplies to Ukraine, arguing they only 'prolong' the conflict\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday criticised the West's delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack Western targets.\n\nThe comment -- which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets -- came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\n- 'Irrecoverable losses' -\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure.\n\n\"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15 year jail sentence.\n\nMore from this section be Well: Information to keep your feet looking and feeling good this summer Very Early Menopause Could Raise Odds for Breast, Ovarian Cancers Lok Sabha Election Results 2024: BJP Workers Celebrate At Headquarters In Delhi | Exclusive Video\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"\n\n- 'Burned to the ground' -\n\nPutin was also probed about what a victory for former US President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for US-Russia relations -- an issue the Russian leader shrugged off.\n\n\"By and large there's no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever he called Trump's recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilisation of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nTrump became the first former US head of state ever convicted of a crime last week after a New York jury found him guilty of 34 felony charges in a hush money case.\n\nTrump, who faces an election in November that could see him return to the White House, has praised Putin as a \"smart guy\".\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed US journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the US and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" Putin said.\n\nbur-kat/rox", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8163692874", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:13:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:13:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:12:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/5/putin-warns-west-over-ukraine-armaments-nuclear-arsenal-in-news-conference", "title": "Putin warns West over Ukraine armaments, nuclear arsenal in news conference", "body": "Russia's president reiterated that attacking NATO countries was a 'crazy' idea but warned against Ukraine interference.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has warned that his country would not rule out using nuclear weapons if its sovereignty or territory were threatened.\n\nOn Wednesday, Putin met in person with leaders from international news agencies, including Reuters and The Associated Press, for the first time since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.\n\nHe answered questions ranging from the threat of nuclear war to possible repercussions for countries that support Ukraine's efforts to launch attacks within Russian territory.\n\nWhen asked about the prospect of using Russia's nuclear arsenal, Putin said it was not out of the question.\n\n\"For some reason, the West believes that Russia will never use it,\" Putin responded, pointing towards the country's 2020 nuclear doctrine.\n\nIt authorises the Russian government to consider nuclear options if a weapon of mass destruction is used against the country or if \"the very existence of the state is put under threat\".\n\n\"We have a nuclear doctrine. Look what it says. If someone's actions threaten our sovereignty and territorial integrity, we consider it possible for us to use all means at our disposal. This should not be taken lightly, superficially.\"\n\nPutin also took the opportunity once again to brush aside fears that Russia could attack countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).\n\n\"You should not make Russia out to be the enemy. You're only hurting yourself with this, you know?\" Putin said at the news conference.\n\nArticle 5 of the treaty establishes that an attack against one country in the organisation is considered an attack against all members.\n\nPutin has repeatedly dismissed the idea of launching an attack on NATO, despite tensions with its member states.\n\nBut Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told CBS News earlier this year that Putin's \"aggression\" could reach Europe, prompting a NATO response. And in April, Germany's top military leader said \"an attack against NATO soil could be possible\" in five to eight years.\n\nStill, Putin reiterated his stance on Wednesday. \"They thought that Russia wanted to attack NATO,\" he said. \"Have you gone completely crazy? That is as thick as this table. Who came up with this? It is just complete nonsense, you know? Total rubbish.\"\n\nHowever, Putin also hinted at the possibility of heightened tensions - and even \"asymmetrical\" military steps - if Western countries like Germany and the United States were to supply Ukraine with weapons used on Russian soil.\n\nHe explained that the use of certain weapons, including the use of advanced missile technology, would be tantamount to participation in Russia's war with Ukraine.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" he said.\n\n\"If they consider it possible to deliver such weapons to the combat zone to launch strikes on our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same type to some regions of the world where they can be used to launch strikes on sensitive facilities of the countries that do it to Russia?\"\n\nHis remarks came after Germany decided in January to supply Leopard 2A6 battle tanks to Ukraine. And last month, both Germany and the US agreed to allow Ukraine to use certain missiles to hit targets inside Russia.\n\nThe Associated Press reported earlier on Wednesday that Ukraine has indeed used US weapons to strike within Russia, though Washington restricts which arms can be used.\n\nAdvanced weapons like the Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS) and other long-range missiles remain off-limits.\n\nAsked about the prospect of a wider range of Western missiles being approved for Ukraine's use in Russia, Putin was defiant: \"We will improve our air defence systems and destroy We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine,\" instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasize that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a The official was not authorised to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nPutin claimed that using some Western-supplied weapons involves military personnel of those countries controlling the missiles and selecting targets, and therefore he said Moscow could take \"asymmetrical\" steps elsewhere in the world. {"uri": "8163551439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:40:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:40:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:39:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/putin-long-range-weapons-countries-target-western-states-6399617-Jun2024/", "title": "Putin considering arming countries that could strike Western states after arms shipments to Ukraine", "body": "He declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses.\n\nRUSSIAN PRESIDENT VLADIMIR Putin has criticised the delivery of long-range weapons to Ukraine by Western countries, arguing Moscow could arm other countries with similar weapons to attack targets in the West.\n\nThe comment - which Putin made at a rare press conference with foreign news outlets - came after several Western countries including the United States gave Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia, a move Moscow has called a grave miscalculation.\n\n\"If someone thinks it is possible to supply such weapons to a warzone to attack our territory and create problems for us, why don't we have the right to supply weapons of the same class to regions of the world where there will be strikes on sensitive facilities of those (Western) countries,\" Putin said.\n\n\"That is, the response can be asymmetric. We will think about it,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"Delivering arms to a warzone is always bad. Even more so if those who are delivering are not just delivering weapons but also controlling them. This is a very serious and very dangerous step,\" Putin said.\n\nThe Russian leader singled out Germany, saying that when the first German-supplied tanks \"appeared on Ukrainian soil, it provoked a moral and ethical shock in Russia\" because of the legacy of World War II.\n\nReferring to German authorities, he said: \"When they say that there will be more missiles which will hit targets on Russian territory, this definitively destroys Russian-German relations.\"\n\nHe also said today that Russia did not harbour any \"imperial ambitions\" and dismissed as \"bollocks\" talk about supposed Russian intentions to attack NATO countries.\n\n\"There is no need to look for something that is not there... There is no need to look for some imperial ambitions of ours. There are none,\" Putin said.\n\n'Irrecoverable losses'\n\nSitting opposite representatives from news outlets including AFP, Putin repeated that his country \"did not start the war against Ukraine\", instead blaming a pro-Western revolution in 2014.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that Russia started the war in Ukraine. I would like to emphasise that nobody in the West, in Europe, wants to remember how this tragedy started,\" Putin said.\n\nHe declined to give the number of Russia's battlefield losses in the more than two-year conflict, saying only that Ukraine's were five times higher.\n\n\"I can tell you that as a rule, no one talks about it,\" Putin said, when asked why Russia had not yet disclosed a figure.\n\n\"If we talk about irrecoverable losses, the ratio is one to five,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe issue of military casualties is extremely sensitive in Russia, where all criticism of the conflict is banned and \"spreading false information\" about the army carries a maximum 15-year jail sentence.\n\nWhen asked about the killing of AFP video journalist Arman Soldin in Ukraine last year, likely as a result of Russian rocket fire, Putin indicated Moscow was ready to help investigate.\n\n\"We will do everything in our power,\" he said.\n\n\"We are ready to do this work. I do not know how it could be done in practice since this person died in a warzone.\"\n\n'Burned to the ground'\n\nPutin was also probed about what a victory for former US President Donald Trump or incumbent Joe Biden would mean for US-Russia relations - an issue the Russian leader shrugged off.\n\n\"By and large there's no difference,\" he said.\n\nHowever he called Trump's recent criminal charges for business fraud politically motivated, arguing his conviction \"burned\" the idea that Washington was a leading democracy.\n\n\"It is obvious all over the world that the prosecution of Trump... is simply the utilisation of the judicial system during an internal political struggle,\" Putin said.\n\n\"Their supposed leadership in the sphere of democracy is being burned to the ground,\" the Russian leader added.\n\nTrump became the first former US head of state ever convicted of a crime last week after a New York jury found him guilty of 34 felony charges in a hush money case.\n\nTrump, who faces an election in November that could see him return to the White House, has praised Putin as a \"smart guy\".\n\nPutin also said Russia and the United States were in \"constant contact\" over a possible prisoner exchange that would free jailed US journalist Evan Gershkovich who was arrested on espionage charges last year.\n\n\"The relevant services in the US and Russia are in constant contact with one another and of course they will decide only on the basis of reciprocity,\" Putin said.\n\nPutin also had a comment on the conflict in Palestine and Israel.\n\n\"What is happening now in Gaza in response to the terrorist attack on Israel, does not resemble a war. It is a kind of total destruction of the civilian population.\"\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024", "source": {"uri": "thejournal.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheJournal.ie"}, "authors": [{"uri":
